evidence.pdf_reference: sample was named BiWO-Ti50i. The samples previously obtained were metallised with low Pt content (0.5 wt) following a photodeposition method. 30For this purpose, a necessary amount of H 2 PtCl 6 (Aldrich 99.9) as the metallic precursor was added to a solution of 2-propanol (0.3 M) used as a sacrificial agent.Afterwards, the suspension of the catalyst in this solution was irradiated under a continuous flow of N 2 to avoid reoxidation, with an Osram Ultra-Vitalux lamp with a sun-like radiation spectrum and a

species has been claimed to have a positive influence on photoactivity, despite its lower efficiency when compared to metallic nanoparticles.In this case, the role can be explained by a successive reductionoxidation process under the illumination of a photocatalyst. 38 All the photocatalysts were tested in the CO 2 photo-reduction under several reaction conditions.When UV light was switched on, the products were continuously monitored until reaching stable conditions.The main detected product was CH 4 .

The photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 with H 2 O to produce CH 4 in the gas phase was carried out in the presence of two Bi 2 WO 6 -based materials.For this purpose, single Bi 2 WO 6 and a coupled Bi 2 WO 6 -TiO 2 system were synthesised and metallised with Pt, through a Pt photodeposition method.Then, the samples were characterised and the photocatalytic activity was evaluated in a continuous fluidised-bed reactor irradiated with UV light.Single Bi 2 WO 6 presents an interesting behaviour under H 2 O rich

behaviour under H 2 O rich conditions.In particular, the metallisation improves the material's performance for CH 4 formation, while the TiO 2 addition to Bi 2 WO 6 increases the CH 4 yield only at low H 2 OCO 2 ratio.The Bi 2 WO 6 -TiO 2 system metallised with a Pt photocatalyst displayed the highest CH 4 yield among all the prepared photocatalysts.The stability of the system can be enhanced through the addition of a blue phosphor to the reactant mixture, especially under H 2 O rich conditions.

can be observed in the heterostructure as a consequence of coupling of Bi 2 WO 6 with TiO 2 -P25.In this sense, BiWO-Ti50i displays better CH 4 yields than both single materials. On the other hand, the right part of Fig. 4B displays the obtained yields with the platinised materials.In this case, it is obvious that platinisation plays an interesting role in CO 2 photo-reduction.The two platinised samples with and without TiO 2 exhibit great improvements associated with the Pt presence.It has been claimed

Please find the category of Light_source and Lamp from the provided context which describe an solar chemical experiment.
The generation condition of the extraction is given: If Light_source is Solar or Solar Simulator, Lamp is always Solar Simulator.

evidence.pdf_reference: with a dual X-ray source of Al K (h) 1486.6 eV at 120 W and 30 mA.The samples were outgassed in the prechamber of the instrument at 150 C up to a pressure of 2 10 -8 Torr to remove chemisorbed water from the surface. A continuous gas-solid photocatalytic fluidised-bed reactor was used to perform the photocatalytic tests.A more detailed description of the photoreactor can be found in previous studies. 32,33The reactor was illuminated by two ultravioletlight-emitting diode (UV-LED) modules positioned in

(UV-LED) modules positioned in front of the Pyrex windows.Each UV-LED module consisted of 40 pieces (supplied by Nichia Corporation) with a wavelength peak of 365 38 nm.The light intensity emitted by the UV-LEDs and entering into reactor was 90 mW cm -2 .The reaction temperature was controlled by a PID controller connected to a heating system and installed in the reactor. In the first configuration, a gas stream of CO 2 (flow rate of 30 L h -1 (STP) controlled by mass flow controllers, Brooks Instruments)

radiation spectrum and a main emission line in the UVA range at 365 nm.An irradiation intensity of 60 W m -2 was used for 2 h, after which the powders were filtered, repeatedly washed and dried overnight at 110 C.The names for these materials will be related to those of the samples without platinum, being in this case: Pt-BW and Pt-BiWO-Ti50i. The crystalline phase and the degree of crystallinity of the samples were estimated by X-ray diffraction (XRD).XRD pat-terns were obtained on a Siemens D-501

performed using a Philips CM200 instrument.The samples were dispersed in ethanol using an ultrasonicator and dropped on a copper grid. UV-vis spectra were recorded by using a Cary 100 (Varian) spectrometer in the diffuse reflectance mode (R) and transformed to a magnitude proportional to the extinction coefficient (K) through the Kubelka-Munk function, F(R).For the measurements, pellets of a mixture of samples with BaSO 4 that do not absorb in the UV-vis radiation range (white standard) were prepared.The
